caption: www.theatlantic.com

data.message: How absurd that he calls the money in his bank account a "fictional number" - the money we all have in the bank is very real, though it is handled virtually today instead of in the form of tangible currency. That virtualization has been a key ingredient in the emergence of a global economy. He's not just putting down the gaming industry - it seems he just doesn't appreciate commerce as a whole.

"Blow intends to shake up this juvenile hegemony with The Witness, a single-player exploration-puzzle game set on a mysterious abandoned island. In a medium still awaiting its quantum intellectual leap, Blow aims to make The Witness a groundbreaking piece of interactive art—a sort of Citizen Kane of video games."  .... Um, Robin and Rand Miller made Myst in the early 1990s.
he sounds like a tool.
Interesting that he took his fictional money and bought a real car and condo with it.

"I have a nice car now."  Hardly. The guy drives a Tesla Roadster, confirmed green chic hipster.  I also find it ironic that he has books on eastern philosophy but he mentions his wealth repeatedly.  "Oh all that money I don't need?  Hahaha.  Who needs money?  It's a tool." etc etc ad nauseum.  Ever noticed how it's always the people with money that claim to not need it?  Funny how that works.  Not to be a complete hater, I'm glad he's going against the mainstream, my field doesn't need another Modern Warfare 32 or whatever lame iteration they're on that has some innocuous graphical improvement.  =)

I like the part where he plays games that don't give him the experience he's after, then complains that games don't give the types of experiences he after, as if there is nothing else. All forms of media have thier own Call of Duty's, this is nothing specific to games. There are a ton of games that have artistic merit. Braid wasn't even that great a work as far as art goes. The gameplay was interesting while it lasted (and it didn't last that long) but the story that was told was conveyed poorly.

I agree, Alex Ames. I'd put it in the same bucket as Bioshock. He (and the author) seem to forget games like Katamari Damacy, Grim Fandango, or Myst. (When they described Witness, I immediately thought that it sounded an awful lot like Myst, too.) I think I am most irritated by the author's lack of knowledge in the field and uncritical worship of JB. What Jon Blow says he's trying to do is interesting, but he's far from the only person doing "serious" games (a recent one being Dear Esther, for example). And his major success could easily be ascribed to novel gameplay rather than a nearly impenetrable narrative. The fact that no one seems to get what the game was "about" might indicate an author's inability to communicate well rather than some deeper meaning that we are all too stupid to figure out.

"a low-slung all-electric automotive dynamo that offers a highly realistic simulation of being shot out of a cannon whenever Blow clamps down on the accelerator" I think the author is somewhat in love with the idea of the subject and probably regrets that his book "7 figures:There and Back Again" didn't receive the acclaim or time based indelible mark his Blow left. But let's take a moment to look as forward as Blows deep existential hairstyle experience allows. He and it may, in the end, be as memorable as the time it took to download.

I read it and the author and Blow do not seem like anyone I want to spend time with  Other then ripping off Myst, it sounds like he wants to make boring games with no production values that lose money.  But he'll get to feel superior to everyone else while he does it.

I also watched the video.  Apparently action games are too much for the author's sensitivities.  Probably doesn't like roller coasters either.  Here's the story rewritten for roller coasters.
Most of today's roller coasters are dumb.  It's no longer enough to be pulled up a hill and let gravity take over, now they launch from the start and there are loops and rolls.  The pace is so frenetic that afterwards I just want to lie down somewhere.  But blow plans to change all this by opening an amusement park filled with hilly walking paths and lots of benches.
The paths will cross and intersect and you can go through them in any combination you want.  So you could start on one path that has fountains and switch over to one with flowers on it instead.
Andy, that is fantastic!

I stopped reading about this guy around half way through. I'm kinda done giving my attention to hate mongers.

Studios like That Game Company have been making beautiful art in the medium for years with out feeling the need to tear down what others do. Much more my speed. :)

description: Never mind that they’re now among the most lucrative forms of entertainment in America, video games are juvenile, silly, and intellectually lazy. At least that’s what Jonathan Blow thinks. But the game industry’s harshest critic is also its most cerebral developer, a maverick bent ...
message: Here's that article from The Atlantic about that pretentious auteur I mentioned before. I have nothing nice to say about it.
name: The Most Dangerous Gamer

~orig.caption: www.theatlantic.com
